video.title: Node.js and Express.js - Full Course
video.description:
Learn how to use Node and Express in this comprehensive course. First, you will learn the fundamentals of Node and Express. Then, you will learn to build a complex Rest API. Finally, you will build a MERN app and other Node projects.

✏️ Course developed by John Smilga. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCMZFwxv5l-XtKi693qMJptA

💻 Code: https://github.com/john-smilga/node-express-course

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

⌨️ (01:41​) What Is Node

topLevelComment.author: Chris Rowe
topLevelComment.text: This resource has been absolutely incredible! I did a full stack coding bootcamp about 4 months ago, and we covered all of this on super fast forward. The way this is explained step by step filled in SO many knowledge gaps. I was going a lot of JFM with express in my bootcamp projects (just f**king magic) as-in, I knew what I was supposed to type but didn't know WHY I was adding it. The way middleware worked was kind of mysterious. How the server status codes effected things. Authorization, the whole lot. It wasn't until I watched this to back up my knowledge that I really understood what all of my class examples of express boilerplate was doing. Thank you so much for this resource!

topLevelComment.author: Michael
topLevelComment.text:
I'm in the HTTP module section at 1:45:24 and I keep trying to run 'node app.js' in the terminal and listen on port 5000. Every time I refresh the localhost:5000 page, VSCode spits an error in the terminal that says:

'node:events:491
      throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event'

I've tried to look for solutions to this problem but everyone seems to say that there must be another node process that needs to be killed or something else on that port.

I've made sure there were no typos.
I've terminated all node processes.
I've restarted my computer.
I've run it on different ports.

Nothing seems to prevent me from getting that same error when refreshing the page. I can't successfully swap between different request urls because of it. Anyone else on windows have this problem or have any solutions?

EDIT: I found the issue. The code block was written with if statements in the video, but I had to include the word 'else' in mine for it to not throw an error for some reason. (Note: this was on Windows)

topLevelComment.author: makayla Mayne
topLevelComment.text:
My notes 
Node.js

Browser VS Node 
Node has no DOM --NO BROWSER API 
With node there is no window 
With node we build pure logic without the graphical interface 

require - function to use modules 
process - gives us info about the environment the node app is in 

Modules 
Encapsulated code 
Only sharing the minimum amount 
Every file in node is a module by default 

module.exports{variableyouwanttoexport};

and then in the file you want to import say 

nameofimport = require('directorytofilewithdata.js')

Built in modules 
built by very smart people to use 
built in module 
const os = require('os')
then the moment you say os. 
you have a bunch of the methods from that specfic module
const user = os.userInfo();
console.log(user);

The process.uptime() method is an inbuilt application programming interface of the process module 
which is used to get the number of seconds the Node.js process is running.


Setting up an http module
Express
go into a file called app.js 


Package is a folder that contains javascript code 

Install a package from npm website 
say 
npm i <packageName> 

package.json 
is a manifest file 
What is the use of it ?
All npm packages contain a file, usually in the project root, called package.json - this file holds various metadata relevant to the project. This file is used to give information to npm that allows it to identify the project as well as handle the project's dependencies. It can also contain other metadata such as a project description, the version of the project in a particular distribution, license information, even configuration data - all of which can be vital to both npm and to the end users of the package. The package.json file is normally located at the root directory of a Node.js project.

Here is a minimal package.json:

{
  "name" : "barebones",
  "version" : "0.0.0",
}

Never include node modules they are too large ! 

nodemon will change things automatically

npm install 
will uninstall the node modules 

npx 
run packages globally or locally 
When you run a package using NPX, it searches for the package in the local and global registry, and then it runs the package.

If the package is not already installed, NPX downloads the package files and installs the package,
 but it will only cache the files instead of saving it.
 npx some-package
 
 
 What is an event loop 
 
 
 A blocking operation occurs when the execution of javascript operations is pulsed and must wait for a non-javascript operation to complete executing. By non-javascript operations, I mean operations like reading or writing data to a file, making a network request, reading or persisting data to a database e.t.c.
 
 Promises have resolve and reject 
 
 
 Async/Await makes it easier to write promises. The keyword ‘async’ before a function makes the function return a promise, always. And the keyword await is used inside async functions, which makes the program wait until the Promise resolves.
 Async await helps wait for PROMISES to resolve 
 
 util module

 const util = module('util');

topLevelComment.author: Andrew Dalton
topLevelComment.text:
If you're confused on the event loop, a call back function will ran last because it is a message event. All functions in your program  have to complete before the callback function will run your code. 

So Ex:
Console. log('One')

setTimeout(()=>{
console.log('two')         Callback gets stored into quene until everything finishes running. 
},0)

console.log('three')

It prints out 
One
three
two

and not One, Two, Three.

This is useful because it can run everything while it's getting data from somewhere else, maybe reading a file. If we do it synchronously and we have something that takes a while to load, then everything else will stop and wait for it to get the data back. 

Hope this helps someone lol

topLevelComment.author: Nicosprintos
topLevelComment.text:
It's not a bad course, and it's really great that it's freely available.
But since no one wants to see the flaws and I find criticism more constructive than praise, and more since I would have liked to have something other than uncritical praises to know if I wanted to spend numerous hours on this tutorial, I'll describe the things I didn't liked:

* It's a little slow. If you are not a real beginner, the pace may bother you.
* I would have preferred the Node part to be done in 2 hours instead of 4 hours and 40 minutes, with more time to be spent on Express.
* The instructor's diction is a bit difficult.
* There are no exercises: To memorize, there is nothing more efficient than doing exercises, but as often, you just copy code while listening to explanations.

topLevelComment.author: Tega Akpovbiyor
topLevelComment.text:
I can't thank you enough for this beautiful piece of work John, 3 hours in and I'm still hooked on your practical method of teaching.

I ran into an issue while installing nodemon globally, something about an ExecutionPolicy Preventing me from running script on my windows machine. Here is how I resolved it for anyone facing thesame issue:

1. press the window button your keyboard
2. Type 'PowerShell' and run as an administrator.
3. In your power shell type in the following command: Set-ExecutionPolicy
4. Press 'Enter' and type in 'RemoteSigned' as the response for ExecutionPolicy then press 'Enter' again
5. Press 'y' and press 'Enter' to effect change.

You should be able to install nodemon globally and run "nodemon app.js" from the tutorial on your editor without error. 

We keep pushing till we get there! Good luck!

To make things further easier for you, you need to have an idea on how HTML and CSS are structured, just the basics.

I hope this helps, stay safe.

topLevelComment.author: awonugba seun
topLevelComment.text:
Hello freeCodeCamp, thank you for this great material, I am an android developer and this material is getting me hooked on learning backend, so at 24:04 you listed some global variables, so I decided to read more on noode global variables so I can have a deeper understanding, however there is some sort of confusion even in the Node Js documenetation
***
Global objects#
These objects are available in all modules. The following variables may appear to be global but are not. They exist only in the scope of modules, see the module system documentation:

__dirname
__filename
exports
module
require()
The objects listed here are specific to Node.js. There are built-in objects that are part of the JavaScript language itself, which are also globally accessible.
***

In the same sentence they said the following listed variables, just exactly the global variables listed in your course, they said they may appear to be global variables, but they are now, however, just after listing the variables, they said the above listed variables are globally accesable,

I'm kind of confused here, if they are globally accesable, why cant they be called global variables.

I hope I could get much more clarity on my confusion.

Thanks so much, this is such a great material to explore the world of backend

replies.author: Urmez Panthaki
replies.text:
These objects are available in all modules. The following variables may appear to be global, but are not. 

The sentences above mean that each module in node has access to those 5 variables. Suppose you have a file server.js, this module will have access to all 5 variables within its scope, but since the variables are within the module, they will not be accessible outside it and hence are not global. Hope this helps

topLevelComment.author: Nerketur Kamachi
topLevelComment.text:
So I have a question.  You talk about promises and async await (which is great), but would observables also work here?  I'm coming at this with knowledge of angular which focuses on RxJS, and I like observables.  Aside from the util  functions to convert a promise to an observable, is there another way similar to .promise that will automatically do so?

My guess is no, but I'm not a master of node, so I figured I'd ask before assuming.  :)

replies.author: Nerketur Kamachi
replies.text:
Next question.  Just before talking about how express makes your life easier, you create lots of constants.  Why not reroute the request instead?  So the file you retrieve is the url added to the directory of the resource location.  That's what real webservers do, after all.

It's still a small hassle, but you don't need random constants littering the JS.

And then to make it more responsive, cache the requests made.  (Also done by real webservers)

replies.author: Guido Perdomo
replies.text:
I had the same question. In essence "path.join" doesn't check if the path is valid, while "path.resolve" does. So if you pass the arguments ('/home', '/etc', 'services'), here's what it would return for each:

path.join('/home', '/etc', 'services')
>> /home/etc/services      // maybe unexistant

path.resolve('/home', '/etc', 'services')
>> /etc/services     // because the second arg starts with a '/', it drops the first argument

topLevelComment.text:
Anyone please clarify :
1) If we put await in async func - then it will first execute the instructions where await is present according to order of line.
2) If we don't put await in async func - then it will give result according to instruction execution time i.e the one which will take less time to execute.

Is these Statements correct ?

replies.author: krishnaraj yadav

replies.author: Chitrang Sharma
krishnaraj yadav
replies.text: @Chitrang Sharma ok, so if there are 2 func with sync and async then async func will first execute and inside it the code with await will first execute line-by-line and then other code which does not have await , right ?

replies.author: Chitrang Sharma
replies.text: Async functions are basically asynchronous and we explicitly have no control over them... With await we let's the function to be executed first then the await code will run as obviously it will be dependent on the async function.
